subtitle.Text: For a long time, the kitchen was not going to be mid-renovation, the way that it is.
And it's one of those things, that I think, that necessity, a production constraint, actually made this part of the house better than it would have been if we could have just done whatever we wanted.
'Cause for a long time we were like, "OK, it's just going to be a kitchen, and so we're going to need a bunch of food,"
which we ended up making, "and we're going to need a bunch of appliances, and we're going to need a bunch of utensils,
and a block with kitchen knives in it, and all the kind of stuff that would be in a kitchen." And at some point we just realized we didn't have the bandwidth to...
Of all the rooms in a house, the kitchen, I think, has the most just one-off unique... thingies in it.
'Cause there's all these kitchen appliances, and stuff, that appear nowhere else in a house.
And so at some point we just realized it wasn't going to make sense for us to try to portray that in a literal way, and so I just had the idea,
"What if I just tore the place apart, and the cabinets were sitting on the ground, and the counters were laid up against the wall, and...
it's an old house, and maybe before the family moved in, the kitchen hadn't been updated since the 50s, and so they decided to re-do the kitchen, and they're in the middle of that when you get here."
I think that A, that's hopefully more visually interesting than playing it straight would have been,
and B, it allowed us to make this feel like a believable space in a way that we just wouldn't have been able to do otherwise.
